articles.headline: Woman Cleared in Death Tied to G.M.’s Faulty Ignition Switch
articles.snippet: Ten years after a crash that killed a passenger, a Texas woman’s guilty plea was overturned after it became clear that the switch was to blame.
articles.abstract: Ten years after a crash that killed a passenger, a Texas woman’s guilty plea was overturned after it became clear that the switch was to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: Candice Anderson received the bittersweet news Monday in a Texas courtroom, fighting back tears, and her arm around the mother of the boyfriend she had felt responsible for killing in a car crash 10 years ago.

articles.headline: Protests Flare After Ferguson Police Officer Is Not Indicted
articles.snippet: Darren Wilson was not charged in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., which set off civil unrest over what protesters called a pattern of police brutality against young black men.
articles.abstract: Darren Wilson was not charged in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., which set off civil unrest over what protesters called a pattern of police brutality against young black men.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — A St. Louis County grand jury has brought no criminal charges against Darren Wilson, a white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed African-American teenager, more than three months ago in nearby Ferguson.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: A Place Where Lost Luggage Gets Another Shot
articles.snippet: Unclaimed Baggage Center is a family business tucked away in Scottsboro, Ala., that sells items as varied as iPads, mink furs and mattresses.
articles.abstract: Unclaimed Baggage Center is a family business tucked away in Scottsboro, Ala., that sells items as varied as iPads, mink furs and mattresses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCOTTSBORO, Ala. — It is a secondhand store, one of a kind. Its name, Unclaimed Baggage Center, doesn’t quite say it all. Its shelves are stocked not only with luggage lost, forgotten or ditched by airline passengers; the store also carries all the contents of that stray luggage deemed suitable for purchase.

articles.headline: Saks Flagship Store Is Appraised for Mortgage at $3.7 Billion
articles.snippet: Hudson’s Bay took out a loan against the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship that valued the department store at nearly $4 billion, making it one of the most valuable retail properties in the country.
articles.abstract: Hudson’s Bay took out a loan against the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship that valued the department store at nearly $4 billion, making it one of the most valuable retail properties in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many financiers have tried to make money from retailers through the ground beneath their stores.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Charles V. Bagli

articles.headline: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s Misplaced Rage at Obama’s Treasury Nominee
articles.snippet: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s wrath toward Antonio F. Weiss is misdirected, and her understanding of the inversion deal on which she bases her opposition appears misinformed.
articles.abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s wrath toward Antonio F. Weiss is misdirected, and her understanding of the inversion deal on which she bases her opposition appears misinformed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than 48 hours after President Obama nominated Antonio F. Weiss, a longtime adviser on mergers at the investment bank Lazard and a Democratic supporter, to become the under secretary of Treasury for domestic finance, Senator Elizabeth Warren denounced the appointment and said that she would vote against his confirmation.

articles.headline: A Bearish Hedge Fund Bets Against the Bulls and Still Profits
articles.snippet: Universa Investments, a hedge fund founded by Mark Spitznagel, has found a way to make money in an economic and financial collapse as well as in better times.
articles.abstract: Universa Investments, a hedge fund founded by Mark Spitznagel, has found a way to make money in an economic and financial collapse as well as in better times.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market has been rising for years, hitting new highs almost every week. So how is it that one of Wall Street’s most bearish investors can claim to have profited strongly over this period?

articles.headline: Honda Failed to Report Defects’ Full Human Toll
articles.snippet: An audit found that the automaker did not inform United States regulators of 1,729 claims of fatalities and injuries linked to a potential defect.
articles.abstract: An audit found that the automaker did not inform United States regulators of 1,729 claims of fatalities and injuries linked to a potential defect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Honda Motor, already facing rising scrutiny over its handling of defective airbags, grossly underreported to federal regulators the number of deaths and injury claims linked to possible defects in its vehicles for more than 10 years, the Japanese automaker disclosed on Monday.

articles.headline: A Nuclear Deal for U.S. and Iran Slips Away Again
articles.snippet: Negotiations carried on in secret for months, but despite a thaw between the governments’ top envoys, the end result is only another extension.
articles.abstract: Negotiations carried on in secret for months, but despite a thaw between the governments’ top envoys, the end result is only another extension.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — By the time Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart checked into a luxury hotel near the famous beaches of Oman earlier this month, a long-sought deal that has eluded the last two American presidents to roll back Tehran’s nuclear program seemed to be slipping out of reach.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Michael R. Gordon and Peter Baker

articles.headline: In Protests From Midwest to Both Coasts, Fury Boils Over
articles.snippet: Ferguson became a scene of chaos, anger and grief after a grand jury declined to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.
articles.abstract: Ferguson became a scene of chaos, anger and grief after a grand jury declined to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Months of anger and frustration, in the end, led only to more anger and frustration.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Security in Ferguson Is Tightened After Night of Unrest
articles.snippet: Gov. Jay Nixon deployed 2,200 troops to Ferguson, Mo., in an effort to avoid a repetition of Monday night’s violence, and broadly expanded their role in keeping the peace.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon deployed 2,200 troops to Ferguson, Mo., in an effort to avoid a repetition of Monday night’s violence, and broadly expanded their role in keeping the peace.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said on Tuesday that he would increase the number of National Guard troops in this suburban St. Louis city and broadly expand their role in keeping the peace, after a night of arson, looting and rampaging demonstrators showed that weeks of preparation for a grand jury decision in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown had failed to prevent violence.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Amid Conflicting Accounts, Trusting Darren Wilson
articles.snippet: In testimony from roughly 60 witnesses, there were varying accounts of the critical final moments, when Michael Brown stopped running, turned and moved back toward Officer Darren Wilson.
articles.abstract: In testimony from roughly 60 witnesses, there were varying accounts of the critical final moments, when Michael Brown stopped running, turned and moved back toward Officer Darren Wilson.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the end, it seems, it all came down to Officer Darren Wilson himself.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Campbell Robertson, Erik Eckholm and Richard A. Oppel Jr
